googletrans: Roberto D'Angelo and Francesca Fedeli: A life lesson our son's illness has taught us

en: "I love paper, and I love technology," says physicist and former sheep herder Kate Stone, who's spent the past decade working to unite the two. Her experiments combine regular paper with conductive inks and tiny circuit boards to offer a unique, magical experience. To date, applications include a newspaper embedded with audio and video, posters that display energy usage in real time, and the extremely nifty paper drumkit and set of DJ decks she demonstrates onstage.
ru: «Я обожаю бумагу и технику», — говорит Кейт Стоун, физик и бывшая перегонщица овец, работавшая последние 10 лет над объединением этих вещей. Её эксперименты с обычной бумагой, токопроводящими чернилами и крошечными схемами приводят к созданию уникальных, магических вещей. Сегодня среди её изобретений — газета с возможностью прослушивания звука и просмотра видео, плакат, отражающий в реальном времени количество затрачиваемой электроэнергии, и супер новшество — бумажная ударная установка и диджейский пульт, работу которых она демонстрирует на сцене.

en: Philosopher John Searle lays out the case for studying human consciousness -- and systematically shoots down some of the common objections to taking it seriously. As we learn more about the brain processes that cause awareness, accepting that consciousness is a biological phenomenon is an important first step. And no, he says, consciousness is not a massive computer simulation.
ru: Философ Джон Сёрл раскрывает тему изучения человеческого сознания и один за другим опровергает связанные с этим мифы, мешающие науке. По мере того, как мы больше узнаём о процессах в мозге и их связи с сознанием, нам остаётся только принять, что сознание —  это биологический феномен. И уж чем сознание точно не является —  так это компьютерной симуляцией (снято на TEDxCERN).
opus-mt: The philosopher John Surl reveals the subject of learning about human consciousness and one after another refutes the myths involved that hinder science. As we learn more about brain processes and their relationship to consciousness, we have only to accept that consciousness is a biological phenomenon. And what's not exactly consciousness is a computer simulation (shot on TEDxCERN).
googletrans: Philosopher John Searle reveals the topic of the study of human consciousness and one by one refutes the myths associated with this that interfere with science. As we learn more about the processes in the brain and their connection with consciousness, we can only accept that consciousness is a biological phenomenon. And what consciousness is definitely not is a computer simulation (filmed at TEDxCERN).

ru: Джон Сёрл: Мифы и реальность сознания
opus-mt: John Surl: Myths and the Reality of the Mind

en: Once it's created, plastic (almost) never dies. While in 12th grade Miranda Wang and Jeanny Yao went in search of a new bacteria to biodegrade plastic -- specifically by breaking down phthalates, a harmful plasticizer. They found an answer surprisingly close to home.

en: Bernie Krause has been recording wild soundscapes -- the wind in the trees, the chirping of birds, the subtle sounds of insect larvae -- for 45 years. In that time, he has seen many environments radically altered by humans, sometimes even by practices thought to be environmentally safe. A surprising look at what we can learn through nature's symphonies, from the grunting of a sea anemone to the sad calls of a beaver in mourning.
ru: Уже на протяжении 45 лет Берни Крауз ведёт запись диких звуковых пейзажей — ветра в лесу, щебетания птиц, едва различимых звуков личинок насекомых. За это время он повидал множество примеров радикального изменения окружающей среды методами, которые доселе считались экологически безопасными. Неожиданный взгляд на изучение действительности с помощью природных симфоний: от урчания актиний до траурного плача бобра.
opus-mt: For 45 years now, Bernie Krause has been recording wild sound landscapes — wind in the woods, chirping birds, and barely visible insect larvae. During that time, he had seen many examples of radical environmental change in methods that were already considered environmentally sound. en: For some reason, says educator Al Vernacchio, the metaphors for talking about sex in the US all come from baseball -- scoring, getting to first base, etc. The problem is, this frames sex as a competition, with a winner and a loser. Instead, he suggests a new metaphor, one that's more about shared pleasure, discussion and agreement, fulfillment and enjoyment. Let's talk about … pizza.
ru: Преподаватель Аль Верначчио рассказывает о том, что в США большинство метафор, описывающих половой акт, основаны на бейсбольном сленге — «заработать очки», «дойти до первой базы»  и т.д. Такая модель представляет секс как соревнование, в котором всегда есть победитель и проигравший. Взамен этой модели он предлагает новую, основанную на разделении удовольствия, обсуждении и согласии, удовлетворении и радости. Итак, поговорим о ...пицце.
opus-mt: Professor Al Vernaccio reports that in the United States, most metaphors describing sexual intercourse are based on baseball slang — "to earn points", "to go to first base", etc. Such a model represents sex as a competition in which there is always a winner and a loser. Instead, he proposes a new model based on sharing pleasure, discussion, and harmony, satisfaction, and joy. So, let's talk about... pizza.

en: Over 85 percent of all pancreatic cancers are diagnosed late, when someone has less than two percent chance of survival. How could this be? Jack Andraka talks about how he developed a promising early detection test for pancreatic cancer that’s super cheap, effective and non-invasive -- all before his 16th birthday.

Джек Андрака рассказывает о том, как он в своём юном 15-летнем возрасте изобрёл многообещающий вид анализа для раннего диагностирования рака поджелудочной железы, который, кроме того, очень дешёв, эффективен и не инвазивен.

Над проведением в жизнь этой новой идеи работают четыре крупных мыслителя: исследователь дельфинов Дайана Рейс, музыкант Питер Гэбриел, основоположник Интернета вещей Нил Гершенфелд и один из отцов Интернета Винт Серф.

en: Building a skyscraper? Forget about steel and concrete, says architect Michael Green, and build it out of … wood. As he details in this intriguing talk, it's not only possible to build safe wooden structures up to 30 stories tall (and, he hopes, higher), it's necessary.

en: When the son of the president of a desperately poor country starts buying mansions and sportscars on an official monthly salary of $7,000, Charmian Gooch suggests, corruption is probably somewhere in the picture. In a blistering, eye-opening talk (and through several specific examples), she details how global corruption trackers follow the money -- to some surprisingly familiar faces.

В своей порывистой, разоблачающей речи, на примере нескольких конкретных дел, она подробно рассказывает о том, как охотники за коррупционерами идут по следу грязных денег и встречают... удивительно знакомые лица.

en: The border between our physical world and the digital information surrounding us has been getting thinner and thinner. Designer and engineer Jinha Lee wants to dissolve it altogether. As he demonstrates in this short, gasp-inducing talk, his ideas include a pen that penetrates into a screen to draw 3D models and SpaceTop, a computer desktop prototype that lets you reach through the screen to manipulate digital objects.
ru: Граница между реальностью и виртуальностью становится всё более прозрачной. Дизайнер и инженер Джинха Ли хочет объединить цифровое и физическое. В своём вдохновляющем выступлении исследователь демонстрирует ручку, которая проникает за экран и рисует объёмные модели, и прототип настольного компьютера, позволяющего оказаться в цифровой реальности и совершать манипуляции виртуальными объектами.

en: Collecting global health data was an imperfect science: Workers tramped through villages to knock on doors and ask questions, wrote the answers on paper forms, then input the data -- and from this gappy information, countries would make huge decisions. Data geek Joel Selanikio talks through the sea change in collecting health data in the past decade -- starting with the PalmPilot and Hotmail, and now moving into the cloud. (Filmed at TEDxAustin.)
ru: Сбор данных в области глобального здравоохранения ‒ наука несовершенная. Работники обходили деревни, стуча в двери и задавая вопросы, записывали ответы в бумажные бланки, а позже заносили информацию в компьютер. На основе этих скудных данных государства принимали важные решения. Энтузиаст в сфере сбора информации Джоэл Селаникио рассуждает о радикальных изменениях в способе сбора данных в области здравоохранения за последнее десятилетие, начиная с карманных компьютеров и электронной почты и заканчивая глобальной сетью. (Снято на TEDxAustin)

On the basis of these meagre data, States have taken important decisions. The information-gathering enthusiast Joel Selanico talks about radical changes in the way health data are collected over the past decade, from pocket computers and e-mail to the global network. (Cancelled on TEDxAustin)
googletrans: Global health data collection is an imperfect science. en: It's a standard assumption in the West: As a society progresses, it eventually becomes a capitalist, multi-party democracy. Right? Eric X. Li, a Chinese investor and political scientist, begs to differ. In this provocative, boundary-pushing talk, he asks his audience to consider that there's more than one way to run a successful modern nation.
ru: На Западе принято думать, что любое общество в результате развития станет капиталистическим, многопартийным и демократическим. Так ли это? Эрик Ли — инвестор и политолог из Китая — настаивает на обратном. В своём провокационном выступлении он просит зрителей задуматься об идее того, что существует более чем один способ управления успешной современной страной.
opus-mt: In the West, it is customary to think that any society will become capitalist, multi-party and democratic as a result of development. Is that so? Eric Lee, an investor and political scientist from China, insists otherwise. In his provocative speech, he asks the audience to think about the idea that there is more than one way to manage a successful modern country.
googletrans: In the West, it is customary to think that any society as a result of development will become capitalist, multi-party and democratic. Is it so? Eric Li, an investor and political scientist from China, insists otherwise. In his provocative speech, he asks viewers to reflect on the idea that there is more than one way to run a successful modern country.

en: Eric X. Li: A tale of two political systems
ru: Эрик Ли: Сказка о двух политических системах
opus-mt: Eric Lee: A story about two political systems
googletrans: Eric Lee: A Tale of Two Political Systems

en: Scaremongers play on the idea that robots will simply replace people on the job. In fact, they can become our essential collaborators, freeing us up to spend time on less mundane and mechanical challenges. Rodney Brooks points out how valuable this could be as the number of working-age adults drops and the number of retirees swells. He introduces us to Baxter, the robot with eyes that move and arms that react to touch, which could work alongside an aging population -- and learn to help them at home, too.
ru: Паникёры утверждают, что роботы просто заменят людей на рабочем месте. На самом деле роботы могут стать незаменимыми помощниками, которые освобождают наше время для решения менее рутинных проблем и выполнения механической работы. Родни Брукс обращает внимание на то, насколько это может быть ценно в свете того, что количество трудоспособного населения снижается, а процент людей, вышедших на пенсию, растёт. Он представляет нам Бакстера, робота, который может двигать глазами и реагирует на прикосновение. Бакстер мог бы работать вместе со стареющим населением, и даже помогать пожилым людям дома.
opus-mt: Panicers claim robots will just replace people in the workplace. In fact, robots can become indispensable helpers, who are freeing our time to solve less routine problems and perform mechanical work. Rodney Brooks points out how valuable this can be given the fact that the number of working-age people is declining and the percentage of people retired is increasing. He represents Baxter, a robot who can move his eyes and react to touch. Baxter could work with an ageing population, even help the elderly at home.
googletrans: Alarmists argue that robots will simply replace humans in the workplace. In fact, robots can become indispensable assistants that free up our time to solve less routine problems and perform mechanical work. Rodney Brooks draws attention to how valuable this can be in light of the fact that the working-age population is declining and the percentage of people retiring is growing. He introduces us to Baxter, a robot that can move its eyes and respond to touch. Baxter could work alongside an aging population, and even help the elderly at home.

en: Rodney Brooks: Why we will rely on robots
ru: Родни Брукс: Почему мы будем полагаться на роботов
opus-mt: Rodney Brooks: Why do we rely on robots?
googletrans: Rodney Brooks: Why we will rely on robots

en: The gastric brooding frog lays its eggs just like any other frog -- then swallows them whole to incubate. That is, it did until it went extinct 30 years ago. Paleontologist Michael Archer makes a case to bring back the gastric brooding frog and the thylacine, commonly known as the Tasmanian tiger.
ru: Лягушка-реобатрахус откладывает свои яйца так же, как и все остальные лягушки, а затем проглатывает их целиком, чтобы выносить. То есть, так было, пока они не вымерли 30 лет назад. Палеонтолог Майкл Арчер проводит исследования, чтобы вернуть к жизни реобатрахусов и сумчатого волка, широко известного как тасманийский волк.
opus-mt: Reobatrachus frog lays its eggs the same as all the other frogs, and then swallows them all to carry them out. I mean, it was until they were extinct 30 years ago. Paleontologist Michael Archer is doing research to bring back to life the rebatrahus and the twilight wolf commonly known as the Tasmanian wolf.
googletrans: The rheobatrachus frog lays its eggs like all other frogs and then swallows them whole to carry them out. That is, it was until they became extinct 30 years ago. Paleontologist Michael Archer is conducting research to bring back to life rheobatrachus and the marsupial wolf, commonly known as the Tasmanian wolf.

en: Michael Archer: How we'll resurrect the gastric brooding frog, the Tasmanian tiger

opus-mt: Michael Archer: How are we gonna bring back the Reubatrahus frog and the Wolf Wolf?
googletrans: Michael Archer: How we resurrect the rheobatrachus frog and the marsupial wolf

en: The New Yorker receives around 1,000 cartoons each week; it only publishes about 17 of them. In this hilarious, fast-paced, and insightful talk, the magazine's longstanding cartoon editor and self-proclaimed "humor analyst" Bob Mankoff dissects the comedy within just some of the "idea drawings" featured in the magazine, explaining what works, what doesn't, and why.
ru: The New Yorker получает около 1 000 карикатур каждую неделю; из них публикуется только около 17.  В этом удивительном, динамичном и глубоком выступлении давнишний редактор отдела карикатур и самопровозглашённый «аналитик юмора» Боб Манкофф раскрывает юмор при помощи всего нескольких «зарисовок идей», показанных в журнале, объясняя, что работает, что нет и почему.
opus-mt: The New Yorker receives about 1,000 caricatures every week; only about 17 of them are published.  In this amazing, dynamic and in-depth performance, Bob Mankoff, a long-standing cartoon editor and self-proclaimed "humor analyst," reveals humor with only a few "smart ideas" shown in the magazine, explaining what works, what does not, and why.
googletrans: The New Yorker receives about 1,000 cartoons every week; of these, only about 17 are published. In this amazing, dynamic, and insightful talk, longtime cartoon editor and self-proclaimed "humor analyst" Bob Mankoff breaks down humor with just a few "idea sketches" shown in the magazine, explaining what works, what doesn't, and why.

en: Bob Mankoff: Anatomy of a New Yorker cartoon
ru: Боб Манкофф: Анатомия карикатур журнала The New Yorker
opus-mt: Bob Mankoff: Anatomy of The New Yorker Caricatures

en: As a young surgeon, Peter Attia felt contempt for a patient with diabetes. She was overweight, he thought, and thus responsible for the fact that she needed a foot amputation. But years later, Attia received an unpleasant medical surprise that led him to wonder: is our understanding of diabetes right? Could the precursors to diabetes cause obesity, and not the other way around? A look at how assumptions may be leading us to wage the wrong medical war.
ru: Будучи молодым хирургом, Питер Аттия однажды испытал презрение к пациентке с диабетом. Тогда он посчитал, что ее нежелание бороться с лишним весом привело пострадавшую к необходимости ампутации ноги. Однако через несколько лет самого Аттия ждал неприятный медицинский сюрприз, который заставил его задуматься: а правильно ли мы понимаем природу диабета? Возможно ли, что симптомы предшествующие диабету, приводят к ожирению, а не наоборот? Видео о том, как наши первоначальные убеждения могут привести к целой цепочке неправильных медицинских заключений.
opus-mt: As a young surgeon, Peter Attia once experienced contempt for a patient with diabetes. At that time, he felt that her reluctance to fight the weight of the victim had led to the need for amputation of her leg. However, after a few years, Attia himself was awaiting a unpleasant medical surprise that made him wonder: Are we right in understanding the nature of diabetes? Is it possible that symptoms of pre-diabetics lead to obesity rather than the other way around? A video of how our initial beliefs can lead to a chain of incorrect medical reports.
googletrans: As a young surgeon, Peter Attiya once experienced contempt for a diabetic patient. Then he considered that her unwillingness to fight overweight led the victim to the need to amputate her leg. However, a few years later, Attius himself was in for an unpleasant medical surprise that made him wonder: do we understand the nature of diabetes correctly? Is it possible that the symptoms that precede diabetes lead to obesity, and not vice versa? Video about how our initial beliefs can lead to a whole chain of wrong medical conclusions.

en: Peter Attia: Is the obesity crisis hiding a bigger problem?
ru: Питер Аттия: А что, если мы ошибаемся насчет диабета?
opus-mt: What if we're wrong about diabetes?
googletrans: Peter Attiya: What if we're wrong about diabetes?

en: When Lesley Hazleton was writing a biography of Muhammad, she was struck by something: The night he received the revelation of the Koran, according to early accounts, his first reaction was doubt, awe, even fear. And yet this experience became the bedrock of his belief. Hazleton calls for a new appreciation of doubt and questioning as the foundation of faith -- and an end to fundamentalism of all kinds.
ru: Во время работы над биографией пророка Мухаммеда, Лесли Хазлтон озадачил один момент: в ночь, когда Мухаммеду явилось откровение Корана, согласно древним источникам, его первой реакцией были сомнения, благоговейный трепет и даже страх. Но, в итоге, испытанное стало основой его веры. Хазлтон призывает к переосмыслению сомнений и неуверенности, как черты, где начинает вера и заканчивается фундаментализм.
opus-mt: During his work on the biography of the prophet Muhammad, Leslie Hazlton was perplexed by one point: the night that the Koran was revealed to Mohammed, according to ancient sources, his first reaction was doubt, awe - inspiring fear, and even fear. But in the end, the test became the foundation of his faith. Hazlton calls for a rethinking of doubt and uncertainty, as a feature where faith begins and fundamentalism ends.
googletrans: While working on a biography of the Prophet Muhammad, Leslie Hazleton was puzzled by one moment: on the night when the revelation of the Koran appeared to Muhammad, according to ancient sources, his first reaction was doubt, awe and even fear. But in the end, what he experienced became the foundation of his faith. Hazleton calls for a rethinking of doubt and uncertainty as the lines where faith begins and fundamentalism ends.

en: Lesley Hazleton: The doubt essential to faith
ru: Лесли Хазлтон: Вере присущи сомнения
opus-mt: Leslie Hazlton: Faith is a doubt.
googletrans: Leslie Hazleton: Faith Has Doubt

en: Photographer Camille Seaman has been chasing storms for 5 years. In this talk she shows stunning, surreal photos of the heavens in tumult.
ru: Фотограф Камилла Симан гоняется за штормами на течение 5-ти лет. В этой беседе она показывает потрясающие сюрреалистические фотографии грозового неба.
opus-mt: A photographer named Camille Siman has been chasing storms for five years. In this conversation, she shows amazing surrealistic photos of the storm sky.
googletrans: Photographer Camille Siman has been chasing storms for 5 years. In this conversation, she shows stunning surreal photographs of a stormy sky.

en: In 1985, architect Paul Pholeros was challenged to "stop people getting sick" in a small indigenous community in south Australia. And it meant thinking way beyond medicine. In this sparky, interactive talk, Pholeros shares his work with Healthabitat, which works to reduce poverty through practical design fixes -- in Australia and beyond.
ru: В 1985 году глава медицинской службы, управляемой коренными жителями, пригласил архитектора Пола Фолероса поучаствовать в «плане, чтобы люди перестали болеть» в небольшой общине аборигенов южной Австралии. Ключевые моменты: думать вне рамок медицины и улучшать среду обитания. В этой живой, интерактивной беседе Фолерос описывает проекты, проводимые «Хелсхабитат» — организацией, которую он в настоящее время возглавляет, чья деятельность направлена на снижение уровня бедности путём улучшения конструкции различных сооружений в Австралии и не только.
opus-mt: In 1985, the head of the Aboriginal-led health service invited architect Paul Foleros to participate in a "plan to stop people from getting sick" in a small community of Southern Australian Aboriginals. Key points are to think outside the medical framework and to improve the environment. In this live, interactive conversation, Foleros describes the projects carried out by Helshabitat, an organization that he is currently leading, whose activities are aimed at reducing poverty by improving the design of different structures in Australia and not just.
googletrans: In 1985, the head of the Indigenous Medical Service invited architect Paul Foleros to participate in a "plan to stop people getting sick" in a small Aboriginal community in South Australia. Key points: think beyond medicine and improve the environment. In this lively, interactive conversation, Foleros describes the projects being run by Healthhabitat, an organization he currently leads that aims to alleviate poverty by improving the design of various structures in Australia and beyond.

en: Paul Pholeros: How to reduce poverty? Fix homes

opus-mt: Paul Foleros: How to reduce poverty? Fixing houses
googletrans: Paul Foleros: How to reduce poverty? repair houses

en: A refugee now living in the US, Joseph Kim tells the story of his life in North Korea during the famine years. He's begun to create a new life -- but he still searches for the family he lost.
ru: Беженец, проживающий сейчас в США, Джозеф Ким рассказывает историю своей жизни в Северной Корее во время великого голода. Он начал строить новую жизнь, но он всё ещё ищет семью, которую он потерял.
opus-mt: The refugee now living in the United States, Joseph Kim, tells the story of his life in North Korea during the great famine. He started building a new life, but he's still looking for the family he lost.
googletrans: A refugee now living in the United States, Joseph Kim tells the story of his life in North Korea during the Great Famine. He has begun to build a new life, but he is still looking for the family he lost.

opus-mt: The family I lost in North Korea. And the family I bought.
googletrans: Joseph Kim: The Family I Lost in North Korea. And the family that I have acquired.

en: Tech communities are booming all over Africa, says Nairobi-based Juliana Rotich, cofounder of the open-source software Ushahidi. But it remains challenging to get and stay connected in a region with frequent blackouts and spotty Internet hookups. So Rotich and friends developed BRCK, offering resilient connectivity for the developing world.
ru: «В Африке технологические сообщества растут как на дрожжах», — говорит жительница Найроби Джулиана Ротич, одна из создателей компании Ushahidi, разрабатывающей общедоступное программное обеспечение. Но из-за постоянных перебоев с электричеством и труднодоступных источников интернета бывает довольно трудно оставаться на связи. Поэтому Джулиана и её друзья создали BRCK — прибор, обеспечивающий надежный доступ в Интернет в развивающихся странах.
opus-mt: "In Africa, technological communities grow like yeasts," says Nairobi's resident Juliana Rotic, one of the creators of Ushahidi, who is developing public software. But the constant power outages and hard-to-reach Internet sources make it difficult to stay in touch. So Juliana and her friends created BRKK, a tool that provides reliable Internet access in developing countries.
googletrans: “In Africa, tech communities are growing by leaps and bounds,” says Nairobi resident Juliana Rotich, co-founder of open source software company Ushahidi. But due to constant power outages and hard-to-reach Internet sources, it can be quite difficult to stay connected. So Juliana and her friends created BRCK, a device that provides reliable Internet access in developing countries.

en: Juliana Rotich: Meet BRCK, Internet access built for Africa
ru: Джулиана Ротич: Встречайте BRCK, созданный для доступа в Интернет в Африке
opus-mt: Juliana Rottic: Meet BRKK, created for Internet access in Africa
googletrans: Giuliana Rotich: Meet BRCK, built for Internet access in Africa

en: The 2007-2008 financial crisis, you might think, was an unpredictable one-time crash. But Didier Sornette and his Financial Crisis Observatory have plotted a set of early warning signs for unstable, growing systems, tracking the moment when any bubble is about to pop. (And he's seeing it happen again, right now.)
ru: Считается, что финансовый кризис 2007-2008 гг. был непредсказуемым единовременным крахом. Но Дидье Сорнетт и его Обсерватория Финансовых Кризисов разработали систему предупреждающих знаков для нестабильных растущих систем, чтобы отследить тот момент, когда пузырь вот-вот лопнет. (И он считает, что сейчас это происходит снова).
opus-mt: The financial crisis is believed to be in 2007-2008. was an unpredictable one-time collapse. But Didier Sornett and his Financial Crisis Observatory have developed a warning system for unstable growing systems to track the moment when the bubble is about to burst. (And he thinks it's happening again)
googletrans: It is believed that the financial crisis of 2007-2008. was an unpredictable one-time collapse. But Didier Sornette and his Observatory of Financial Crises have developed a system of warning signs for unstable growing systems to watch for when the bubble is about to burst. (And he believes that now it is happening again).

en: Didier Sornette: How we can predict the next financial crisis
ru: Дидье Сорнетт: Как можно предсказать следующий финансовый кризис
opus-mt: Didier Sornett: How can the next financial crisis be predicted?
googletrans: Didier Sornette: How to predict the next financial crisis

en: There's no actual law against women driving in Saudi Arabia. But it's forbidden. Two years ago, Manal al-Sharif decided to encourage women to drive by doing so -- and filming herself for YouTube. Hear her story of what happened next.
ru: В Саудовской Аравии нет закона, запрещающего женщинам водить. Но это запрещено. Два года назад Маналь аль-Шариф решила своим примером воодушевить женщин, желающих водить, и выложила свою запись на YouTube. Послушайте ее историю о том, что было дальше.
opus-mt: There is no law in Saudi Arabia prohibiting women from driving. But it's forbidden. Two years ago, Manal Al-Sharif decided to use her example to encourage women to drive, and posted her tape on YouTube. Listen to her story about what happened next.
googletrans: There is no law in Saudi Arabia prohibiting women from driving. But it's forbidden. Two years ago, Manal al-Sharif decided to inspire women who want to drive by her example and posted her entry on YouTube. Hear her story about what happened next.

en: Manal al-Sharif: A Saudi woman who dared to drive
ru: Маналь аль-Шариф: Женщина из Саудовской Аравии, осмелившаяся сесть за руль
opus-mt: Manal Al-Sharif: Saudi woman who dared to drive
googletrans: Manal al-Sharif: The Saudi woman who dared to drive

en: As a novelist, Daniel Suarez spins dystopian tales of the future. But on the TEDGlobal stage, he talks us through a real-life scenario we all need to know more about: the rise of autonomous robotic weapons of war. Advanced drones, automated weapons and AI-powered intelligence-gathering tools, he suggests, could take the decision to make war out of the hands of humans.
ru: Как писатель, Дэниэл Суарес любит сочинять мрачные истории о будущем. Но на сцену TEDGlobal он вышел, чтобы поговорить о том, что происходит в реальной жизни, и о чём всем нам не мешает больше знать: увеличение использования автономного роботизированного оружия. По его мнению, современные модели беспилотных боевых самолётов, автоматическое оружие и разведывательные системы, оснащённые элементами искусственного интеллекта, могут принимать решения о начале военных действий самостоятельно, без участия людей.
opus-mt: As a writer, Daniel Suarez likes to write dark stories about the future. But on TEDGlobal, he went out to talk about what's going on in real life, and what we all know more about is the increased use of autonomous robotic weapons. In his view, modern models of unmanned combat aircraft, automatic weapons and intelligence systems equipped with artificial intelligence can decide to launch hostilities on their own, without the involvement of people.
googletrans: As a writer, Daniel Suarez loves to write dark stories about the future. But he took the stage at TEDGlobal to talk about what's happening in real life, and what we all need to know more about: the increase in the use of autonomous robotic weapons. In his opinion, modern models of unmanned combat aircraft, automatic weapons and reconnaissance systems equipped with elements of artificial intelligence can make decisions on the start of hostilities on their own, without the participation of people.

en: Daniel Suarez: The kill decision shouldn't belong to a robot
ru: Дэниэл Суарес: Смертный приговор не должен выноситься роботами
opus-mt: Daniel Suarez: The death penalty should not be imposed by robots
googletrans: Daniel Suarez: Death sentence should not be handed down by robots

en: Greece has been the poster child for European economic crisis, but former Prime Minister George Papandreou wonders if it's just a preview of what's to come. “Our democracies," he says, "are trapped by systems that are too big to fail, or more accurately, too big to control” -- while "politicians like me have lost the trust of their peoples." How to solve it? Have citizens re-engage more directly in a new democratic bargain.
ru: Греция стала примером последствий экономического кризиса в Европе, но бывший премьер-министр Георгиос Папандреу полагает, что это может быть только началом. «Наша демократия, — говорит он, — в ловушке систем, слишком больших, чтобы ошибаться, вернее, слишком больших, чтобы их контролировать», в то время как «такие политики, как я, потеряли доверие своего народа». Что же делать? Привлечь граждан к более прямому участию в новой демократической политике.
opus-mt: Greece was an example of the consequences of the economic crisis in Europe, but former Prime Minister Georgios Papandreou believes that this can only be the beginning. "Our democracy," he says, is trapped in systems too big to be wrong, or rather too big to control," while "politics like me have lost the trust of their people." What should we do? Encourage citizens to participate more directly in the new democratic policy.
googletrans: Greece has become an example of the consequences of the economic crisis in Europe, but former Prime Minister Georgios Papandreou believes that this could only be the beginning. “Our democracy,” he says, “is trapped in systems too big to fail, or rather too big to control,” while “politicians like me have lost the trust of their people.” What to do? Engage citizens to participate more directly in new democratic politics.

en: George Papandreou: Imagine a European democracy without borders
ru: Георгиос Папандреу: Представьте себе европейскую демократию без границ
opus-mt: Georgios Papandreou: Imagine European democracy without borders
googletrans: Georgios Papandreou: Imagine a European democracy without borders

en: In a robot lab at TEDGlobal, Raffaello D'Andrea demos his flying quadcopters: robots that think like athletes, solving physical problems with algorithms that help them learn. In a series of nifty demos, D'Andrea show drones that play catch, balance and make decisions together -- and watch out for an I-want-this-now demo of Kinect-controlled quads.
ru: На семинаре по роботостроению на TEDGlobal Раффаэлло Д'Андреа  продемонстрировал публике летающие аппараты-квадролёты: роботов, обладающих способностью мыслить, как спортсмены-атлеты, и решать проблемы физического мира с помощью обучающих алгоритмов. На примере нескольких забавных демонстраций Д'Андреа показал, как беспилотные летательные аппараты могут играть в мяч, балансировать разные предметы и совместно принимать решения. Также не пропустите демонстрацию того, как можно управлять квадом через сенсорный игровой контроллер Kinect — мечта любого владельца игровой приставки.

en: For 28 years, Denise Herzing has spent five months each summer living with a pod of Atlantic spotted dolphins, following three generations of family relationships and behaviors. Было очевидно, что они общаются между собой, но является ли это языком? Могли бы люди его тоже использовать? В подтверждение этой идеи Дениз делится с нами потрясающими новыми исследованиями.

en: Domestic violence and sexual abuse are often called "women’s issues.” But in this bold, blunt talk, Jackson Katz points out that these are intrinsically men’s issues -- and shows how these violent behaviors are tied to definitions of manhood. A clarion call for us all -- women and men -- to call out unacceptable behavior and be leaders of change.

Громкий призыв ко всем нам — к женщинам и мужчинам — обличать неприемлемое поведение и быть проводниками изменений.

en: Why can't two slices of pizza be used as a slide clicker? Why shouldn't you make music with ketchup? In this charming talk, inventor Jay Silver talks about the urge to play with the world around you. He shares some of his messiest inventions, and demos MaKey MaKey, a kit for hacking everyday objects.
ru: Почему два куска пиццы не могут стать пультом? Почему бы вам не создавать музыку с помощью кетчупа? В этом очаровательном выступлении, изобретатель Джей Сильвер рассказывает о желании играть с окружающим миром. Он делится своими интересными изобретениями, и демонстрирует Makey Makey, устройство, «взламывающее» предметы обихода.
opus-mt: Why can't two pieces of pizza become a remote? Why don't you make music with ketchup? In this charming performance, inventor Jay Silver talks about the desire to play with the world around him. He shares his interesting inventions, and he shows Macey Macey, a device that hacks into objects.
googletrans: Why can't two slices of pizza become a remote control? Why don't you make music with ketchup? In this charming talk, inventor Jay Silver talks about his desire to play with the world around him. He shares his interesting inventions and demonstrates the Makey Makey, a device that "hacks" household items.

en: Jay Silver: Hack a banana, make a keyboard!
ru: Джей Сильвер: Нарежьте банан, сделайте клавиатуру!
opus-mt: J. Silver: Cut the banana, get the keyboard!

en: Can a person disappear in plain sight? That’s the question Liu Bolin‘s remarkable work seems to ask. The Beijing-based artist is sometimes called “The Invisible Man” because in nearly all his art, Bolin is front and center — and completely unseen. He aims to draw attention to social and political issues by dissolving into the background.
ru: Может ли человек исчезнуть из виду прямо посреди магазина, улицы, студии новостей? Это вопрос, которым задаётся Лю Болин в своих выдающихся работах. Этого художника из Пекина иногда называют «Человек-невидимка», поскольку в большинстве своих работ, Болин является центром картины, будучи при этом скрытым от глаз. Его цель — привлечь внимание к социальным и политическим проблемам, растворяющимся в пространстве.
opus-mt: Can a man disappear in the middle of a store, a street, a news studio? It's a question that Liu Bolin asks in his outstanding work. This artist from Beijing is sometimes called "Invisible Man", because in most of his works Bolin is the center of the painting, while being hidden from the eye. Its aim is to draw attention to the social and political problems that are disappearing in space.
googletrans: Can a person disappear from sight right in the middle of a store, a street, a news studio? This is the question that Liu Bolin asks in his outstanding writings. This Beijing-based artist is sometimes referred to as "The Invisible Man" because in most of his work, Bolin is the center of the painting while being hidden from view. Its goal is to draw attention to social and political issues that are dissolving into space.

en: Liu Bolin: The invisible man
ru: Лю Болин: Человек-невидимка
opus-mt: Liu Bolin: Invisible Man
googletrans: Liu Bolin: The Invisible Man

en: In our digital world, social relations have become mediated by data. Without even realizing it, we’re barricading ourselves against strangeness -- people and ideas that don't fit the patterns of who we already know, what we already like and where we’ve already been. A call for technology to deliver us to what and who we need, even if it’s unfamiliar. (Filmed at TED@Intel.)
ru: В нашем электронном мире, социальные отношения определяются информацией. Даже не осознавая, мы отгораживаем себя от неизвестности — от людей и идей, не соответствующих шаблонам тех, кого мы знаем, что мы любим и где мы были. Это звоночек для технологий, которые могут привести нас к тому, что нам нужно, даже если это нам не знакомо. (Снято на TED@Intel)
opus-mt: In our electronic world, social relations are determined by information. Without realizing it, we keep ourselves away from the unknown — from people and ideas that do not conform to the patterns of those we know, what we love, and where we have been. It's a call for technology that can lead us to what we need, even if we don't know it. (Cancelled on TED@Intel)
googletrans: In our electronic world, social relations are determined by information. Without even realizing it, we fence ourselves off from the unknown—from people and ideas that don't fit the molds of those we know, love, and where we've been. This is a call for technologies that can lead us to what we need, even if it is not familiar to us. (Shot at TED@Intel)

en: Maria Bezaitis: The surprising need for strangeness

opus-mt: Maria Bezaitis: The Amazing Need for Unknown
googletrans: Maria Bezaitis: The Surprising Need for the Unknown

en: Clinical psychologist Meg Jay has a bold message for twentysomethings: Contrary to popular belief, your 20s are not a throwaway decade. In this provocative talk, Jay says that just because marriage, work and kids are happening later in life, doesn’t mean you can’t start planning now. She gives 3 pieces of advice for how twentysomethings can re-claim adulthood in the defining decade of their lives.
ru: Клиническому психологу Мег Джей есть что сказать тем, кому сейчас 20 с лишним. Несмотря на распространённое заблуждение, третий десяток не является бесполезным периодом жизни. В своём побуждающем к размышлениям выступлении Джей говорит, что пусть мы стали позже вступать в брак, начинать карьеру и заводить детей — это отнюдь не значит, что мы не можем готовиться и строить планы прямо сейчас. Джей даёт три совета о том, как молодые взрослые могут с умом провести определяющие десятилетие в преддверии зрелости.
opus-mt: Meg Jay's clinical psychologist has something to say to those who are over 20 now. Despite widespread error, the third dozen is not a useless period of life. In his thought-taking speech, Jay says that letting us get married later, start a career and have children is not to say that we can't prepare and plan right now. Jay gives three tips on how young adults can wisely spend a defining decade in anticipation of maturity.
googletrans: Clinical psychologist Meg Jay has something to say to those now in their 20s. Despite popular misconception, the third decade is not a useless period of life. In his thought-provoking talk, Jay says that just because we're getting married later, starting careers, and having kids doesn't mean we can't prepare and make plans right now. Jay gives three tips on how young adults can wisely spend the defining decade leading up to adulthood.

en: Meg Jay: Why 30 is not the new 20
ru: Мег Джей: Почему 30 — это не новые 20
opus-mt: Meg Jay: Why 30 isn't new 20
googletrans: Meg Jay: Why 30 isn't the new 20

en: Sir Ken Robinson outlines 3 principles crucial for the human mind to flourish -- and how current education culture works against them. In a funny, stirring talk he tells us how to get out of the educational "death valley" we now face, and how to nurture our youngest generations with a climate of possibility.
ru: Сэр Кен Робинсон выделяет три принципа, которые критически важны для процветания человеческого разума, а также говорит о том, как современная культура образования работает против них. С юмором и энергичностью он рассказывает о том, как выбраться из «долины смерти» в образовании, в которой мы оказались, и как воспитывать подрастающие поколения в атмосфере возможностей.
opus-mt: Sir Ken Robinson highlights three principles that are critical to the prosperity of the human mind, as well as how the modern culture of education works against them. With humour and energy, he talks about how to get out of the "drop of death" in the education we find ourselves in, and how to raise younger generations in an atmosphere of opportunity.

With humor and energy, he talks about how to get out of the "valley of death" in education in which we find ourselves, and how to educate the next generation in an atmosphere of opportunity.

en: Ken Robinson: How to escape education's death valley

en: Leaving a high-flying job in consulting, Angela Lee Duckworth took a job teaching math to seventh graders in a New York public school. She quickly realized that IQ wasn’t the only thing separating the successful students from those who struggled. Here, she explains her theory of “grit” as a predictor of success.
ru: Уволившись с чрезвычайно успешной работы в сфере консалтинга, Анджела Ли Дакворт стала преподавать математику семиклассникам в нью-йоркской государственной школе. Она быстро осознала, что успешные ученики отличались от неуспешных не только уровнем IQ. В своём выступлении она объясняет свою теорию «твёрдости характера» как залога успеха.
opus-mt: After quitting her extremely successful consultancy work, Angela Lee Duckworth began teaching math to seven-grade students at the New York State School. She quickly realized that successful students differed from unsuccessful students not only at IQ level. In her presentation, she explained her theory of "sequences of character" as a key to success.
googletrans: After quitting her hugely successful consulting job, Angela Lee Duckworth began teaching seventh grade math at a New York public school. en: Why, why, why does our education system look so similar to the way it did 50 years ago? Millions of students were failing then, as they are now -- and it’s because we’re clinging to a business model that clearly doesn’t work. Education advocate Geoffrey Canada dares the system to look at the data, think about the customers and make systematic shifts in order to help greater numbers of kids excel.
ru: Почему, ну почему же наша система образования так похожа на ту, которая существовала 50 лет назад? Миллионы учеников проваливались так же, как и сейчас. Это происходит из-за того, что мы изо всех сил держимся за бизнес-модель, которая определённо не работает. Пропагандист образования Джеффри Канада бросает вызов системе: взглянуть на данные, подумать об учащихся и систематически вносить изменения, которые помогут добиться успеха большему количеству детей.

en: Young poet, educator and activist Malcolm London performs his stirring poem about life on the front lines of high school. He tells of the "oceans of adolescence" who come to school "but never learn to swim," of "masculinity mimicked by men who grew up with no fathers." Beautiful, lyrical, chilling.
ru: Малкольм Лондон, начинающий поэт, учитель и активист, декламирует своё трогательное стихотворение о жизни на передовой старших классов школы. Он говорит об «океанах мальков», которые устремились в школы, «но так никогда и не научились плавать», о «псевдомужественности парней, выросших без отцов». Красиво, эмоционально, проникновенно.

en: Pearl Arredondo grew up in East Los Angeles, the daughter of a high-ranking gang member who was in and out of jail. Many teachers wrote her off as having a problem with authority. Now a teacher herself, she’s creating a different kind of school and telling students her story so that they know it's okay if sometimes homework isn’t the first thing on their minds.
ru: Перл Арредондо — дочь главаря преступной группировки, не раз попадавшего в тюрьму — выросла в восточной части Лос-Анджелеса. Многие учителя списали её со счетов как ребёнка имеющего проблемы с послушанием. Теперь она сама, будучи учителем, создаёт школу, отличную от общепринятых, рассказывает ученикам свою собственную историю жизни и уверяет их что не беда, если домашняя работа не всегда на первом месте в списке их необходимых дел.
opus-mt: Pearl Arredondo, the daughter of a gang leader who had been imprisoned on several occasions, was raised in the eastern part of Los Angeles. Many teachers have written her off as a child with a problem with obedience. Now, as a teacher, she creates a school that is different from what is generally accepted, tells his students her own life story and assures them that it is not a problem if homework is not always the top priority on their list of things to do.

en: It took a life-threatening condition to jolt chemistry teacher Ramsey Musallam out of ten years of “pseudo-teaching” to understand the true role of the educator: to cultivate curiosity. In a fun and personal talk, Musallam gives 3 rules to spark imagination and learning, and get students excited about how the world works.

В шутливой и доверительной беседе, Мусаллам описывает три способа развития воображения, любви к обучению и интереса учеников к познанию того, как устроен мир.
opus-mt: Ramsey Musallam, a chemistry teacher, had to cope with a life-threatening situation in order to recognize that he had been a pseudo-educator for ten years and to realize that the true purpose of the teacher was to cultivate curiosity. en: Until recently, many teachers only got one word of feedback a year: “satisfactory.” And with no feedback, no coaching, there’s just no way to improve. Bill Gates suggests that even great teachers can get better with smart feedback -- and lays out a program from his foundation to bring it to every classroom.

Билл Гейтс считает, что даже отличные учителя могут стать лучше с толковым откликом — и описывает программу своего фонда с целью внедрить её в каждый класс.
opus-mt: Until recently, many teachers received only one response in a year: satisfactory. And without a response, without instruction, there is simply no room for improvement. en: For foreigners, learning to speak Chinese is a hard task. But learning to read the beautiful, often complex characters of the Chinese written language may be less difficult. ShaoLan walks through a simple lesson in recognizing the ideas behind the characters and their meaning -- building from a few simple forms to more complex concepts. Call it Chineasy.

Во время простого урока ШаоЛань показывает, как разгадать суть и значения иероглифов, двигаясь от нескольких простых форм до более сложных понятий. Назовите это Chineasy [англ. China — Китай, easy — простой].

en: In this well-argued talk, Timothy Bartik makes the macro-economic case for preschool education -- and explains why you should be happy to invest in it, even if you don't have kids that age (or kids at all). The economic benefits of well-educated kids, it turns out, go well beyond the altruistic.
ru: В этом хорошо аргументированном выступлении Тимоти Бартик приводит доводы в пользу дошкольного образования и объясняет, почему вам выгодно в него инвестировать, даже если у вас нет детей дошкольного возраста (или вообще нет детей). Оказывается, польза от хорошего образования детей выходит далеко за пределы альтруизма в область экономики. (Записано на TEDxMiamiUniversity)

en: Rita Pierson, a teacher for 40 years, once heard a colleague say, "They don't pay me to like the kids." Her response: "Kids don't learn from people they don’t like.’” A rousing call to educators to believe in their students and actually connect with them on a real, human, personal level.
ru: Рита Пирсон, учитель с 40-летним стажем, однажды услышала, как её коллега сказала: «Мне не платят за то, чтобы я любила детей». Её ответ был таков: «Дети не учатся у тех, кто им не нравится». Это выступление — призыв к педагогам, к тому, чтобы они верили в своих учеников и создавали с ними настоящие, близкие, человеческие взаимоотношения.
opus-mt: Rita Pearson, a 40-year-old teacher, once heard her colleague say, "I don't get paid to love children." Her answer was, "Children don't learn from people they don't like." This statement is a call to educators to believe in their disciples and to build a genuine, close, human relationship with them.
googletrans: Rita Pearson, a teacher of 40 years, once overheard her colleague say, "I don't get paid to love children." Her answer was, "Children don't learn from people they don't like." This speech is a call to teachers to believe in their students and create real, close, human relationships with them.

en: What if Andy Warhol had it wrong, and instead of being famous for 15 minutes, we’re only anonymous for that long? In this short talk, Juan Enriquez looks at the surprisingly permanent effects of digital sharing on our personal privacy. He shares insight from the ancient Greeks to help us deal with our new “digital tattoos.”
ru: Что если Энди Уорхол был не прав, и вместо того, чтобы стать знаменитым на 15 минут, каждый из нас теперь лишь столько и сможет сохранить анонимность? В своём коротком выступлении Хуан Энрикез рассуждает о том, как размещение информации в интернете может оказать поразительно продолжительное влияние на нашу частную жизнь. Опираясь на мудрость древних греков, Энрикез даёт советы о том, как нам быть с «сетевыми татуировками».
opus-mt: What if Andy Warhol was wrong, and instead of becoming famous for 15 minutes, all of us now are only gonna be able to keep our anonymity? en: When Eric Dishman was in college, doctors told him he had 2 to 3 years to live. That was a long time ago. Now, Dishman puts his experience and his expertise as a medical tech specialist together to suggest a bold idea for reinventing health care -- by putting the patient at the center of a treatment team.
ru: Когда Эрик Дишман учился в колледже, врачи сказали, что жить ему осталось от 2 до 3 лет. Это было довольно давно. После того как диагнозы были пересмотрены и успешно прошла трансплантация, Дишман, на основе своего личного опыта и своей экспертизы в качестве ведущего специалиста по медицинским технологиям, предложил новый революционный взгляд на устройство системы здравоохранения — пациент должен быть поставлен в центр команды, проводящей лечение. (Снято на TED@Intel)
opus-mt: When Eric Dishman was in college, doctors said he had two to three years to live. It was a long time ago. After the diagnosis was revised and successfully transplanted, Dishman, based on his personal experience and his expertise as a leading medical technology specialist, proposed a new revolutionary view of the health system — the patient must be placed at the centre of the treatment team. (Cancelled on TED@Intel)
googletrans: When Eric Dishman was in college, doctors said he had 2 to 3 years to live. It was quite a long time ago. After the diagnoses were reviewed and the transplant successfully completed, Dishman, based on his personal experience and his expertise as a leading medical technology specialist, proposed a new revolutionary view of the design of the healthcare system - the patient should be placed at the center of the treatment team. en: What motivates us to work? Contrary to conventional wisdom, it isn't just money. But it's not exactly joy either. It seems that most of us thrive by making constant progress and feeling a sense of purpose. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely presents two eye-opening experiments that reveal our unexpected and nuanced attitudes toward meaning in our work. (Filmed at TEDxRiodelaPlata.)
ru: Что мотивирует на работу? Вопреки общепринятому мнению, это не только деньги. Но это и не только удовольствие. Кажется, что большинство из нас процветают, постоянно продвигаясь вперёд и ощущая целеустремлённость. Поведенческий экономист Дэн Ариэли представляет два поучительных эксперимента, которые показывают наши неожиданные и нюансы отношения к смыслу в нашей работе. (Снято на TEDxRiodelaPlata).
opus-mt: What motivates you to work? Contrary to generally accepted opinion, it is not just money. But it's not just a pleasure. It seems that most of us thrive, constantly moving forward and feeling determined. The behavioral economist Dan Ariely presents two educational experiments that show our unexpected and nuanced attitudes to meaning in our work. (Cancelled on TEDxRiodelaPlata).
googletrans: What motivates you to work? Contrary to popular belief, it's not just money. But it is not only pleasure. Most of us seem to thrive by constantly moving forward and feeling purposeful. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely presents two instructive experiments that reveal our unexpected and nuanced relationship to meaning in our work. (Shot at TEDxRiodelaPlata).

en: Dan Ariely: What makes us feel good about our work?

en: Your smartphone may feel like a friend -- but a true friend would give you a smile once in a while. At TED2013, Keller Rinaudo demos Romo, the smartphone-powered mini robot who can motor along with you on a walk, slide you a cup of coffee across the table, and react to you with programmable expressions.
ru: Ваш смартфон может быть вам другом, но настоящий друг должен вам иногда улыбаться. На конференции TED2013 Келлер Ринаудо демонстрирует Romo, мини-робота, управляемого смартфоном, который может пойти с вами на прогулку, пододвинуть чашку кофе на столе, и реагировать на вас программируемым поведением.

en: At age 12, Freeman Hrabowski marched with Martin Luther King. Now he's president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC), where he works to create an environment that helps under-represented students -- specifically African-American, Latino and low-income learners -- get degrees in math and science. He shares the four pillars of UMBC's approach.
ru: В 12 лет Фриман Грабовски маршировал рядом с Мартином Лютером Кингом. Теперь он президент Мэрилендского университета, в округе Балтимор, (UMBC), где он создаёт среду, помогающую студентам из недостаточно представленных меньшинств, в частности афро-, латино-американцам и малоимущим, преуспевать в науке и математике. Он рассказывает о четырёх основах методики UMBC.

He is now president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC), where he creates an environment that helps students from underrepresented minorities, particularly African-Americans and the poor, to succeed in science and mathematics. He talks about the four basics of UMBC.
googletrans: At age 12, Freeman Grabowski marched alongside Martin Luther King. He is now president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC), where he creates an environment that helps underrepresented minority students, particularly Africans, Hispanics, and the underprivileged, excel in science and math. en: Trivia whiz Ken Jennings has made a career as a keeper of facts; he holds the longest winning streak in history on the U.S. game show Jeopardy. But in 2011, he played a challenge match against supercomputer Watson -- and lost. With humor and humility, Jennings tells us how it felt to have a computer literally beat him at his own game, and also makes the case for good old-fashioned human knowledge. (Filmed at TEDxSeattleU.)
ru: Умник Кен Дженнингс сделал карьеру хранителя фактов; ему принадлежит рекорд самой длинной беспроигрышной серии в американском телешоу «Своя игра». Но в 2011-м он принял вызов от суперкомпьютера «Ватсон»… и проиграл. Скромно и с юмором Дженнингс рассказывает нам о том, каково это — быть сражённым суперкомпьютером в его же игре, а так же защищает старое доброе человеческое знание. (Снято на TEDxSeattleU)
opus-mt: Clever Ken Jennings has made a career as a factkeeper; he holds the record of the longest win-win series on the American television show "The Game." But in 2011, he took a call from Watson's supercomputer... and lost. In a modest way, Jennings tells us what it's like to be fought by a supercomputer in his own game, as well as protecting old human knowledge. (Cancelled on TEDxSeattleU)

Modestly and with humor, Jennings tells us about what it's like to be slain by a supercomputer in his own game, and also defends the good old human knowledge. (Shot at TEDxSeattleU)

en: 3D printing has grown in sophistication since the late 1970s; TED Fellow Skylar Tibbits is shaping the next development, which he calls 4D printing, where the fourth dimension is time. This emerging technology will allow us to print objects that then reshape themselves or self-assemble over time. Think: a printed cube that folds before your eyes, or a printed pipe able to sense the need to expand or contract.
ru: Трёхмерная печать известна уже более тридцати лет. Стипендиат программы TED Fellows Скайлар Тиббитс демонстрирует нам новое направление, называемое им 4D печать, в котором роль четвёртого измерения играет время. Эта технология позволит нам распечатывать объекты, которые трансформируются и собираются самостоятельно за какое-то время. Представьте: распечатанный куб, который собирается прямо у вас на глазах, или труба, способная сообразить, сколько воды вам нужно в данный момент.
opus-mt: The three-dimensional seal has been known for over thirty years. TED Fillows Fellow Skylar Tibbits shows us a new direction called 4D printing, in which time plays the role of the fourth dimension. This technology will allow us to print out objects that are transformed and collected on their own in a while. Imagine a printed cube that's going right in front of your eyes, or a pipe that can figure out how much water you need right now.
googletrans: Three-dimensional printing has been known for over thirty years. Skylar Tibbits, a TED Fellow, is showing us a new direction he calls 4D printing, in which time plays the role of the fourth dimension. This technology will allow us to print objects that transform and assemble on their own over time. Imagine: a printed cube that is assembled right in front of your eyes, or a pipe that can figure out how much water you need at the moment.

en: There is a corruption at the heart of American politics, caused by the dependence of Congressional candidates on funding from the tiniest percentage of citizens. That's the argument at the core of this blistering talk by legal scholar Lawrence Lessig. With rapid-fire visuals, he shows how the funding process weakens the Republic in the most fundamental way, and issues a rallying bipartisan cry that will resonate with many in the U.S. and beyond.
ru: Сама основа американской политической системы поражена коррупцией, чья причина — зависимость кандидатов в Конгресс от спонсорских пожертвований очень небольшого числа граждан. Именно этой проблеме посвящено проникновенное выступление правоведа Лоуренса Лессига. Сочетая рассказ о том, как такое спонсорство разрушает самые основные демократические процессы, а вслед за ними подрывает основы республики, с моментально сменяющимися и яркими картинами, учёный обращается к представителям обоих крупнейших политических партий Америки с призывом объединить усилия, и его слова найдут отклик в сердцах многих слушающих как в Соединённых Штатах, так и за их пределами.
opus-mt: The very foundation of the American political system is struck by corruption, whose cause is the dependence of Congressional candidates on the sponsorship of a very small number of citizens. This is the subject of a far-reaching speech by the legal scholar Lawrence Lassig. Combining the story of how such sponsorship destroys the most basic democratic processes, and then undermines the foundations of the republic, with instant and vivid images, the scientist calls on the representatives of the two major political parties of America to join forces, and his words will find a response in the hearts of many listeners, both within and outside the United States.
googletrans: The very foundation of the American political system is plagued by corruption, which stems from the dependence of congressional candidates on sponsorship donations from a very small number of citizens. Combining the story of how such sponsorship destroys the most basic democratic processes, and after them undermines the foundations of the republic, with momentarily changing and vivid pictures, the scholar appeals to representatives of both of America's largest political parties to join forces, and his words will resonate in the hearts many listeners both in the United States and beyond.

en: Imagine an electric vehicle that can get you to work -- or anywhere in a six-mile radius -- quickly, without traffic frustrations or gasoline. Now imagine you can pick it up and carry it with you. Yes, this souped-up skateboard could change the face of morning commutes.

en: When two people are trying to make a deal -- whether they’re competing or cooperating -- what’s really going on inside their brains? Behavioral economist Colin Camerer shows research that reveals how badly we predict what others are thinking. Bonus: He presents an unexpected study that shows chimpanzees might just be better at it.
ru: Когда два человека заключают сделку — соперники они или напарники — что же происходит у них в голове? Поведенческий экономист Колин Кэмерер демонстрирует исследование, выявляющее, насколько мало мы можем предсказать о том, что думают другие. Он предлагает неожиданные результаты исследований шимпанзе, которые, может быть, справляются с этой задачей лучше нас. (Снято на TEDxCalTech.)
opus-mt: When two people make a deal, whether they are rivals or partners, what happens in their heads? The behavioral economist Colin Cameron shows a study that reveals how little we can predict what others think. He offers unexpected results from chimpanzee studies, which may be better than us. (Cancelled on TEDxCalTech.)

Behavioral economist Colin Camerer demonstrates research that reveals how little we can predict about what others think. He offers unexpected results from research on chimpanzees, who may be better at this task than we are. (Taken at TEDxCalTech.)

en: In the Maasai community where Richard Turere lives with his family, cattle are all-important. But lion attacks were growing more frequent. In this short, inspiring talk, the young inventor shares the solar-powered solution he designed to safely scare the lions away.
ru: В общине масаи, где живёт 13-летний Ричард Турере, крупный рогатый скот имеет большое значение. А нападения на скот со стороны львов случаются всё чаще и чаще. В этом коротком, вдохновляющем монологе, молодой изобретатель рассказывает о решении этой проблемы, которым стало устройство на солнечных батареях, предназначенное для безопасного отпугивания львов подальше от загонов скота.

en: Our bodies and homes are covered in microbes -- some good for us, some bad for us. As we learn more about the germs and microbes who share our living spaces, TED Fellow Jessica Green asks: Can we design buildings that encourage happy, healthy microbial environments?

en: Composer and conductor Eric Whitacre has inspired millions by bringing together "virtual choirs," singers from many countries spliced together on video. Now, for the first time ever, he creates the experience in real time, as 32 singers from around the world Skype in to join an onstage choir (assembled from three local colleges) for an epic performance of Whitacre's "Cloudburst," based on a poem by Octavio Paz.
ru: Композитор и дирижёр Эрик Витакер вдохновил миллионы слушателей своими «виртуальными хорами», объединяющими певцов из разных стран с помощью видеотехнологий. В этот раз, впервые, он совершит это в прямом эфире: 32 хориста из разных стран с помощью Skype присоединятся к хору на сцене (состоящему из студентов трёх университетов) и исполнят монументальный «Облачный раскат» авторства Витакера на слова стихотворения Октавио Паса.
opus-mt: The songwriter and conductor Eric Vitaker inspired millions of listeners with his "virtual choirs" that bring together singers from different countries through video technology. en: Today we know the molecular cause of 4,000 diseases, but treatments are available for only 250 of them. So what’s taking so long? Geneticist and physician Francis Collins explains why systematic drug discovery is imperative, even for rare and complex diseases, and offers a few solutions -- like teaching old drugs new tricks.
ru: На сегодняшний день нам известны молекулярные предпосылки 4 000 болезней, но лекарства найдены только для 250 из них. Так в чем же задержка? Врач и генетик Фрэнсис Коллинз объясняет, почему крайне необходимы систематические исследования лекарств, даже от редких и сложных заболеваний, и предлагает некоторые решения, наподобие использования старых лекарств по-новому.
opus-mt: Today, we know the molecular conditions of 4,000 diseases, but only 250 of them have been found. So what's the delay? en: As a child growing up in North Korea, Hyeonseo Lee thought her country was “the best on the planet.” It wasn't until the famine of the 90s that she began to wonder. Hers is a harrowing, personal tale of survival and hope -- and a powerful reminder of those who face constant danger, even when the border is far behind.

en: The Internet connects billions of people and machines; it's the backbone of modern life. But tech pioneer Danny Hillis thinks the Internet just wasn't designed to grow this big -- and he fears that one big cyber-attack or glitch could shut it down and take civilization with it. To head off a digital dark age, he sounds a clarion call to develop a Plan B: a parallel system to fall back on if -- or when -- the Internet crashes.
ru: В 70-е и 80-е годы прошлого века интернет был пронизан духом доверия — пользователей были считанные единицы. Теперь вездесущая сеть, объединяет миллиарды людей, компьютеров и узлов связи, а мы всё более уязвимы перед лицом кибератаки или сбоя в системе. Дэнни Хиллис — человек, стоявший у истоков интернета — утверждает, что сеть не была рассчитана на такой громадный масштаб, и призывает нас задуматься над разработкой Плана Б: независимой резервной системы, на которую можно будет положиться в случае сбоя в интернете.
opus-mt: In the 1970s and 1980s, the Internet was inspired by a spirit of trust, with a few users. Now, the ubiquitous network is bringing together billions of people, computers and communication nodes, and we are increasingly vulnerable to cyber attacks or system failure. Danny Hillis, the man at the source of the Internet, claims that the network was not designed for such a huge scale, and he urges us to think about developing Plan B: an independent backup system that we can rely on in the event of an Internet malfunction.

en: Throughout humankind's history, we've driven species after species extinct: the passenger pigeon, the Eastern cougar, the dodo ... But now, says Stewart Brand, we have the technology (and the biology) to bring back species that humanity wiped out. So -- should we? Which ones? He asks a big question whose answer is closer than you may think.
ru: На протяжении всей истории человечества мы истребляли один вид за другим: исчезли с лица земли странствующий голубь, восточная пума, дронт. Но теперь, как утверждает Стюарт Бранд, в нашем распоряжении есть технологические (и биологические) средства, с помощью которых можно вернуть к жизни истреблённые человеком виды. Но стоит ли? И если да, то какие именно виды? Вопрос, который задаёт нам учёный, очень серьёзен, но найти на него ответ проще, чем можно было бы подумать.

en: Activist and fundraiser Dan Pallotta calls out the double standard that drives our broken relationship to charities. Too many nonprofits, he says, are rewarded for how little they spend -- not for what they get done. Instead of equating frugality with morality, he asks us to start rewarding charities for their big goals and big accomplishments (even if that comes with big expenses). In this bold talk, he says: Let's change the way we think about changing the world.

По его словам, слишком много некоммерческих организаций поощряются не за результаты деятельности, а за низкий уровень расходов. Вместо того чтобы приравнивать нравственность к экономности, он призывает поощрять благотворительные организации за амбициозные цели и больши́е достижения (даже если им сопутствуют больши́е расходы). en: “Desertification is a fancy word for land that is turning to desert,” begins Allan Savory in this quietly powerful talk. And it's happening to about two-thirds of the world’s grasslands, accelerating climate change and causing traditional grazing societies to descend into social chaos. Savory has devoted his life to stopping it. He now believes -- and his work so far shows -- that a surprising factor can protect grasslands and even reclaim degraded land that was once desert.
ru: «Опустынивание — это модное слово означающее землю, которая превращается в пустыню», — спокойно начинает своё яркое выступление Аллан Савори. Этому ужасному явлению подвержены две трети луговых пастбищ по всему миру, что ускоряет изменение климата и является причиной социального кризиса в традиционно скотоводческих хозяйствах. Савори посвятил всю свою жизнь, чтобы приостановить этот процесс. Он считает, и это подтверждается его работами, что с помощью удивительного способа можно предохранить луга, и даже восстановить размытые земли, которые однажды представляли собой пустыню.

en: Bruce Feiler has a radical idea: To deal with the stress of modern family life, go agile. en: An insect's ability to fly is perhaps one of the greatest feats of evolution. Michael Dickinson looks at how a fruit fly takes flight with such delicate wings, thanks to a clever flapping motion and flight muscles that are both powerful and nimble. But the secret ingredient: the incredible fly brain. (Filmed at TEDxCaltech.)
ru: Возможно, способность насекомых летать является одним из величайших достижений эволюции. Майкл Дикинсон расскажет, как обыкновенной комнатной мухе удаётся летать, используя свои сверхчувствительные крылышки, за счёт хитроумного способа движения взмаха крыльев и устройства летательных мышц, которые способны развивать большую силу, а так же стремительно изменять направление движения. Но главный секретный ингредиент — это поразительное устройство мозга мухи. (Снято на TEDxCaltech)

en: How can we measure what makes a school system work? Вы сможете увидеть, какое место занимает ваша страна среди других и что делает некоторые системы эффективнее других.

en: Trinidad and Tobago amassed great wealth in the 1970s thanks to oil. But in 1982, a shocking fact was revealed -- that 2 out of every 3 dollars earmarked for development had been wasted or stolen. This has haunted Afra Raymond for 30 years. Shining a flashlight on a continued history of government corruption, Raymond gives us a reframing of financial crime. (Filmed at TEDxPortofSpain.)
ru: В 1970-х годах Республика Тринидад и Тобаго накопила огромные богатства благодаря природным ресурсам. Но в 1982 году были вскрыты шокирующие факты — 2 из каждых 3 долларов, направленных на развитие были потеряны или украдены. Это не давало покоя Афра Рэймонду на протяжении 30 лет. Проливая свет на продолжающуюся историю государственной коррупции, Рэймонд заставляет нас переосмыслить понятие финансового преступления. (Снято на TEDxPortofSpain)

en: What can economists learn from linguists? Behavioral economist Keith Chen introduces a fascinating pattern from his research: that languages without a concept for the future -- "It rain tomorrow," instead of "It will rain tomorrow" -- correlate strongly with high savings rates.

en: Can we use our brains to directly control machines? Miguel Nicolelis suggests yes, showing how a clever monkey in the US learned to control a robot arm in Japan purely with its thoughts. The research has big implications for quadraplegic people -- and in fact, it powered the exoskeleton that kicked off the 2014 World Cup.
ru: Может ли наш мозг управлять роботами напрямую, без помощи тела? Мигель Николелис рассказывает о выдающемся эксперименте, в котором сообразительная обезьяна из США учится управлять своей виртуальной проекцией, а затем роботом в Японии — всё только силой мысли. Данное исследование имеет большое значение для людей, страдающих тетраплегией (параличом всех четырёх конечностей), и, возможно, для всех нас. (Снято на TEDMED 2012)
opus-mt: Can our brain control robots directly without the help of the body? Miguel Nicolelis describes a remarkable experiment in which a smart ape from the United States learns to control his virtual prose, and then a robot in Japan is just a force of thought. This study is important for people with tetraplagics (paralysis of all four limbs) and perhaps for all of us. (Cancelled on TEDMED 2012)

en: In long-term relationships, we often expect our beloved to be both best friend and erotic partner. But as Esther Perel argues, good and committed sex draws on two conflicting needs: our need for security and our need for surprise. So how do you sustain desire? With wit and eloquence, Perel lets us in on the mystery of erotic intelligence.
ru: В долгосрочных отношениях мы часто ждём, что наш возлюбленный будет и лучшим другом, и эротическим партнёром. В своём остроумном и красноречивом выступлении Перель приоткрывает нам тайну эротического интеллекта.

en: James Glattfelder studies complexity: how an interconnected system -- say, a swarm of birds -- is more than the sum of its parts. And complexity theory, it turns out, can reveal a lot about how the economy works. Glattfelder shares a groundbreaking study of how control flows through the global economy, and how concentration of power in the hands of a shockingly small number leaves us all vulnerable. (Filmed at TEDxZurich.)
ru: Джеймс Б. Глаттфелдер занимается изучением сложных систем: чем объединённая система — например, стая птиц — отличается от суммы её частей. Оказывается, теория сложных систем может пролить свет на то, как работает экономика. Глаттфелдер делится результатами революционного исследования, изучающего контроль над глобальной экономикой, которые говорят о том, что концентрация власти в руках шокирующе малого количества ведущих акционеров делает нас всех уязвимыми. (Снято на TEDxZurich)

Turns out the theory of complex systems can shed light on how the economy works. Glatfelder shares the results of a revolutionary study of global economic control, which suggests that the concentration of power in the hands of a shockingly small number of leading shareholders makes us all vulnerable. (Cancelled on TEDxZurich)
googletrans: James B. Glattfelder studies complex systems: how a combined system, such as a flock of birds, differs from the sum of its parts. en: Imagine a country where girls must sneak out to go to school, with deadly consequences if they get caught learning. This was Afghanistan under the Taliban, and traces of that danger remain today. 22-year-old Shabana Basij-Rasikh runs a school for girls in Afghanistan. She celebrates the power of a family's decision to believe in their daughters -- and tells the story of one brave father who stood up to local threats. (Filmed at TEDxWomen)

Она гордится семьями, которые ценят и верят в своих дочерей, и рассказывает историю одного храброго отца, который противостоял угрозам. (Снято на TEDxWomen)

en: Make a city beautiful, curb corruption. en: There are so many tiny, beautiful, funny, tragic moments in your life -- how are you going to remember them all? Director Cesar Kuriyama shoots one second of video every day as part of an ongoing project to collect all the special bits of his life.
ru: Существует множество крошечных, красивых, забавных, трагических моментов в нашей жизни. Как вы собираетесь запомнить их всех? Режиссёр Цезарь Курияма записывает видео каждый день по одной секунде, которая является частицей непрерывного проекта, цель которого — собрать все особенные моменты его жизни.

en: High school science teacher Tyler DeWitt was ecstatic about a lesson plan on bacteria (how cool!) -- and devastated when his students hated it. The problem was the textbook: it was impossible to understand. He delivers a rousing call for science teachers to ditch the jargon and extreme precision, and instead make science sing through stories and demonstrations. (Filmed at TEDxBeaconStreet.)
ru: Тайлер ДеВитт, преподаватель в средней школе, был в восторге от темы урока, посвящённой бактериям (как круто!) — и шокирован, когда его ученикам она не понравилась. Проблема заключалась в учебнике: его невозможно было понять. Тайлер воодушевлённо призывает преподавателей отбросить узкоспециализированную терминологию и чрезмерную точность и заставить науку зазвучать смешно и интересно, используя истории и наглядные примеры. (Снято на TEDxBeaconStreet)
opus-mt: Tyler DeWitt, a high school teacher, was thrilled with the topic of the bacteria lesson (cool!) - and shocked when his students didn't like her. The problem was a textbook: it was impossible to understand. Tyler is excited to encourage teachers to throw away highly specialized terminology and excessive precision and make science sound funny and interesting, using stories and illustrations. (Cancelled on TEDxBeaconStreet)
googletrans: Tyler DeWitt, a high school teacher, was excited about the topic of the lesson about bacteria (how cool!) - and shocked when his students didn't like it. (Taken at TEDxBeaconStreet)
